{"step_by_step_thinking": "Dentine permeability is influenced by several factors. The smear layer, which is a layer of debris remaining on the surface of the dentine after cutting, can block the dentinal tubules and reduce permeability. The length of the dentinal tubules also affects permeability, as longer tubules allow for more fluid movement. Fluid convection, or the movement of fluid through the tubules, also plays a role in dentine permeability. However, the diffusion coefficient, which is a measure of how quickly a substance can diffuse through a medium, is not directly related to dentine permeability.
